UNPARLIAMENTARY LANGUAGE
(Complaint by Member for Potong Pasir)
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


     Mr Speaker: Order. I have an announcement to make on a matter concerning the conduct of an honourable Member of the House.

    On 4th November 1995, I received a written complaint dated 3rd November 1995 from the Member for Potong Pasir, Mr Chiam See Tong, stating that the Member for Bukit Gombak, Mr Ling How Doong, had uttered certain unparliamentary words at him during the sitting on 3rd November 1995 and asking that the matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges. In another letter dated 7th November 1995, Mr Chiam also mentioned the names of Members who heard these

Column: 317

words uttered by Mr Ling. Mr Chiam's letter (Cols. 407 - 408) to me dated 3rd November 1995 has been circulated to Members.
Mr Chiam's letter (Cols. 407 - 408)


    I did not hear these remarks contained in the complaint of Mr Chiam though I saw Mr Ling engaging in conversation with somebody else. At that moment, I called Mr Ling to order and asked him to resume his seat and reminded Mr Ling to refrain from engaging in conversation with others in the House as that was not the proper way to participate in a debate of the House, whereupon Mr Ling remarked "When he is unparliamentary, why should I be parliamentary to him?".

    On receipt of the complaint by Mr Chiam, I wrote to Mr Ling on 14th November 1995, asking for his response to Mr Chiam's complaint. Mr Ling, in his written explanation on 17th November 1995, said that other than certain words, he could not recall the rest and that he had uttered those words because he was provoked by remarks made by Mr Chiam. Mr Ling's letter (Cols. 409 - 410) to me has also been circulated to Members.
Mr Ling's letter (Cols. 409 - 410)


    I have perused the Official Report of the Parliamentary Debates where it was recorded that Mr Ling had uttered the words that he had admitted to in his letter of 17th November 1995, which language I find to be unparliamentary and, as such, it is a breach of Standing Order 48(4). I am also of the opinion that the words "When he is unparliamentary, why should I be parliamentary to him?", in response to my order to refrain from engaging in conversation with others in the House and to resume his seat, are contemptuous of the Chair and undermine the dignity of the House.

    At a meeting with Mr Ling on 30th November 1995 in my chambers I informed Mr Ling that no matter what the provocation was, he had no excuse to use unparliamentary language in the House. Mr Ling agreed unreservedly to withdraw his unparliamentary remarks contained in the Official Report and to apologise to the House. He will also apologise for being

Column: 318

contemptuous of, and disregarding the authority of the Chair when he continued to remark "When he is unparliamentary, why should I be parliamentary to him?" when called to resume his seat.

    I will now call upon Mr Ling to make his statement.

     Mr Ling How Doong (Bukit Gombak): Mr Speaker, Sir, I unreservedly withdraw the words directed at the Member for Potong Pasir which were recorded in the Official Report.

    I apologise to the House for having affronted its dignity in uttering those words and also for disregarding the authority of the Chair when asked to resume my seat.

     Mr Speaker: May I make it clear to hon. Members that the use of unparliamentary language by Members undermines the dignity and decorum of the House. Under no circumstances should a Member indulge in language that would lower the standing of this House. If a Member has heard unparliamentary language used against him, the proper procedure is for the Member to draw the Speaker's attention to the matter and not to aggravate the situation by using unparliamentary language. The Chair will not hesitate to enforce discipline and order in the House to uphold its good name.

    In my years in the House I cannot recall any similar instance of such unparliamentary language having been used by a Member. I hope that this incident will be the last of its sort.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ELECTRONICS SECTOR
(Growth rate)


    1. Mr John de Payva asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the present double-digit growth of the electronics sector is sustainable.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the electronics industry grew by 23% in 1993, 22% in 1994 and 16% in January-September 1995. This is due to strong global demand for electronic products like personal computers, disk drives and semiconductors.

Column: 320



    However, not all segments did well. The consumer electronics segment declined by 4.6% in the first nine months of this year after expanding by 26% in 1994.

    It is difficult to forecast growth accurately as the electronics industry is fast-moving and volatile. However, based on available information, the outlook appears good. Most analysts expect strong growth to continue up to the first half of 1996 because of the boom in personal computers and the present global shortage of components such as semiconductors. The latest survey of business expectations also shows that a net balance of 39% of electronics firms expect business to improve in the last quarter of 1995 and the first quarter of 1996, compared with 27% in the same period last year. We can expect double-digit growth for 1995 and 1996, though not as high as in 1994.

    Over the longer-term, the prospects for the global electronics industry are good. Dataquest predicts that the global electronics demand will hit US$1.3 trillion by the year 2000. This represents an average annual growth rate of 8.7% over the period 1995-2000, compared to 7.4% over the period 1989-94. In addition, the Asia-Pacific's share of the global electronics demand will also grow from 19% in 1994 to 27% in the year 2000. By continuing to upgrade their core capabilities and moving into high value-added products, our electronics companies will be in a good position to benefit from this world-wide boom.

CHILD CARE CENTRES
(Review of grants)


    2. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Community Development whether there are plans to increase the number of child care centres and review the grants for such centres.

     The Acting Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry will set up more child care centres to meet the needs of parents who require the service. As at the end of October 1995, there were 376 child care centres with 29,343 places. By the

Column: 321

end of FY 95, the target is to provide 402 centres with a total capacity of 30,562 places. The target set for FY 96 is 434 centres to provide for 32,642 places. The Ministry continually monitors the demand for child care services and sets up centres in tandem with demand.

    As for grants, Sir, child care centres set up by voluntary welfare organisations, non-profit organisations and workplaces receive capital grants for equipment and furnishings and for conversion costs. Grants are adequate and MCD will review them periodically as the need arises.

    Then there is a child care subsidy for working mothers which was increased from $130 to $150 for full day care and from $65 to $75 for half day care with effect from April this year. This amounts to a $6.24 million increase in the budget for child care subsidy bringing the total to $40.82 million. Child care subsidies are reviewed on a regular basis in order to keep child care fees affordable and to make them attractive for working mothers to use child care centres.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, would the Minister inform the House where are most of these child care centres being established and whether there are adequate child care centres in the new towns where there is a growing number of young working mothers who have been demanding for additional child care places?

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, we have adequate child care centres as of now. In fact,, as at October this year, there were 2,682 vacancies in child care centres all over the island.

    In our projection for child care centres, we do take into account where the demands are and where the new satellite towns would be. These would be the places where we will concentrate the child care centres.

CABLE NETWORK CONNECTIONS
(Payment by residents of private houses)


    3. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Information and the Arts why residents of private houses are required to

Column: 322

pay for cable network connections whereas Housing and Development Board flat residents obtain their connections free when the network is intended to be the platform for IT2000, a national programme.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, funding for cable TV wiring for both HDB and private residential estates is based on the principle of cost-sharing negotiated between the cable operator and home owners. Much of the cost of installing the cable network in HDB estates is shared between HDB as lessor and SCV. Residents are also required to pay a small installation fee if they wish to subscribe to cable TV and additional TV services. Under the agreement between SCV and HDB, SCV takes over and upgrades the existing central antenna system in all HDB estates and is responsible for their maintenance.

    SCV will apply the same principle of cost-sharing for private housing estates. It is prepared to meet the owners, developers or management corporations of such estates to discuss equitable cost-sharing formulas.

    The HDB-SCV cost sharing formula is probably not appropriate as a model for private estates. HDB estates are a special group. They have a common lessor, are generally consistent in design and have high unit concentrations. There are therefore economies of scale in installation. Private estates are less straightforward. SCV will have to customize installation for each of them.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether it is true that cable TV will also be a platform for IT2000 and whether the Singapore Broadcasting Authority has the intention to link it to every home so that every household can take part in the national programme? May I ask what the Government will do in cases where the private households just cannot afford the link-up?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: For new developments, we will require the installation to be done. For existing developments, this will have to be phased in

Column: 323

gradually and I do not see a problem for most private estates because the cost involved is not huge. If management corporations find it difficult to foot out a high upfront cost, SCV is prepared to negotiate a low upfront installation cost but recover the cost back later in higher subscription costs. But the objective is eventually to have all the households in Singapore wired onto the information highway.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, my point is what if some private households cannot afford or will not do it on the principle that the Government is paying for HDB households? So why should it not pay for private houses since HDB actually shares the cost with Singapore CableVision? When HDB has a deficit, the Government actually gives HDB a grant for covering the deficit which means that in actual fact, in the end, the cable links to HDB flats are being paid for by the Government. In such a case, why should the Government not pay for private houses?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, in general, HDB is not paying more than it would have to pay to maintain the existing cable system, which we call the MATV system, as opposed to the new cable ready central antennae system which we call the CATV system. For new flats which are already wired for cable television, the full cost is recovered from the buyers. For old flats where MATV systems are due for replacement, HDB will pay what it would have to pay anyway for the MATV system and the rest will be topped up by SCV. For flats which already have the MATV system and are not yet due for replacement, HDB will cough up an amount roughly in between zero and what it would have cost them to completely replace the system. So it is not as if the laying of IT infrastructure for HDB estates requires additional funding by HDB. In general, they are paying what they would have to pay anyway.

    I think Mr Heng's question concerns what happens if private housing estates voluntarily opt out from the cable TV system and whether we would require

Column: 324

them by law to install such a system. I think this is a bridge we will cross when we come to it. Let us try it out on a voluntary basis first, find out the extent of their problem before deciding whether legislation is necessary.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, I think the Minister has missed my point. My point is that the HDB's link-up is being paid for by the Government because, although HDB pays for it as a landlord, one must remember that HDB's yearly operating deficit is being funded by the Government through a grant to HDB. If HDB had not paid for this cost, HDB's deficit would be smaller and the Government therefore grants a smaller amount. In this sense, although it is being paid by HDB, it is actually being paid by the Government. And I am saying that if it is being paid for by the Government, then the people of Singapore living in private estates should also get the same benefit.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I do not think that logic applies. HDB estates are generally subsidised. They are not being additionally subsidised for cable television. HDB is paying what it would have to pay anyway for the MATV system. In fact, HDB would have to pay less in the future because the future maintenance of the CATV system would be undertaken by SCV, and not by HDB.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, does the Minister deny that the HDB actually gets a grant from the Government to cover its operating deficit on an annual basis?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Yes, of course, HDB does get such a grant. And it would require less when SCV takes over the central antennae system because the maintenance of that system would then be done by SCV instead of HDB.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, therefore, in such cases, if the HDB dwellers co-pay for the linking up of this cable television network, then the HDB's deficit would be much smaller and the grant would also be smaller. But because HDB now pays the share of the cost and the residents do not have to pay, the grant is bigger.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Those living in housing estates and who subscribe to

Column: 325

SCV would have to pay an installation charge and, in addition, they have to pay a monthly subscription charge.

CONVERSION OF ZEBRA CROSSINGS INTO PUSH-BUTTON PEDESTRIAN CROSSINGS


    4. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Communications whether the Land Transport Authority will convert zebra crossings into push-button pedestrian crossings for greater road safety.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Mr Goh Chee Wee) (for the Minister for Communications): Zebra crossings and push- button crossings are designed to suit different types of roads and traffic and pedestrian volumes. For roads with heavy traffic and pedestrian volumes, push-button pedestrian crossings are more appropriate. At such crossings, push buttons enable pedestrian demand to be recorded, and pedestrians can only cross when a "green man" is displayed. This arrangement enables pedestrians to cross safely while minimising delays to motorists.

    For local access roads with light traffic, zebra crossings are more suitable as they cause minimum inconvenience to both pedestrians and motorists. Pedestrians cross when they see it is safe to do so, while motorists are given advance warning to slow down by road signs. Transverse stripes along the approaches to the crossings slow down traffic and light beacons are installed to make the crossings more conspicuous.

    So both types of crossings are safe when installed and used as designed. The Land Transport Authority will monitor the usage of such crossings and make conversions where appropriate, eg, where traffic and pedestrian volumes have increased.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether, as an immediate measure, certain prominent pre-warning signs like "Stop", "Look", "Walk", could be installed at the zebra crossings as a guide to pedestrians using these crossings?

Column: 326



     Mr Goh Chee Wee: We will certainly take into consideration the suggestion by the Member to help the pedestrians. I think we have to keep on educating the pedestrians on the proper use of zebra crossings.

AUDITORIUMS IN PUBLIC LIBRARIES
(Use by students for study at examination times)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Information and the Arts whether he will consider allowing facilities, such as auditoriums at branch libraries, to be used by students who wish to study outside the home, for two months before and during the General Certificate of Education examinations.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, facilities in public libraries are for members of the public to consult library materials and for holding library activities and programmes. The libraries organise many outreach programmes like talks, library visits for schools, and workshops for members of the public on a regular basis using the auditoriums in the libraries. If we allow only students to use the auditoriums for study at examination times, the libraries would not be able to hold outreach programmes for members of the public during those months. This would deprive library users of such services. Most community centres provide facilities for students to study. The National Library Board compiles a list of such facilities available near the public libraries and these are given out to students who need a place to study.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, what is the frequency in which such programmes are being planned and held in the auditorium? We are asking that the students be allowed to use the auditoriums for two months before and during the GCE examinations, and not for the whole year.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the actual numbers here. But the facilities are intensively used.

PROMOTION EXERCISE FOR TEACHERS
(Unhappiness over evaluation of teachers' performances)


    6. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that there is unhappiness over the evaluation of teachers' performances in the recent promotion exercise and what he proposes to do about it.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Education): Sir, the promotion exercises this year were mainly for classroom teachers. The evaluation and recommendation of teachers for promotion was done by panels in schools comprising the Principal, Vice-Principal and Heads of Department. Every teacher eligible for promotion was considered.

    In the two exercises carried out, about 7,500 teachers were promoted, the largest ever in the Education Service. The system to evaluate and recommend teachers for promotion is a fair and rigorous one, relying closely on the intimate knowledge of school supervisors serving on the panels. I am satisfied that teachers have been given fair consideration with regard to their promotion. In every promotion exercise, there will be a number who are unhappy at not being promoted. However, not all teachers can be promoted during this year's exercises given the large number of officers in the service. ADVANCE MEDICAL DIRECTIVE BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Health (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Rapidly advancing medical technology presents human societies with new moral challenges. Today, modern medical technology is able to sustain essential physiological functions and technically prolong life in the final stages of terminal illness. Sometimes, it does no more than prolong the process of dying.

    The choice of treatment alternatives to doctors and patients will widen in the future. But we must all still die. Whatever new technology may bring forth, we will still have to make difficult choices either on our own behalf or on behalf of others in the last days of life. Medical technology is after all only our servant, and not our master.

    When the patient is of sound mind, when he is compos mentis, he decides for himself. He may consult, he may be advised, but the decision is his. Under common law, he is autonomous. The problem arises when the patient is no longer able to decide for himself. Today, when this happens, the doctor will consult with the family who will be asked to make a decision on behalf of the patient. When the decision involves withholding or withdrawing extraordinary life-sustaining treatment, it places a heavy burden on family members. The experience varies. Some families will decide firmly one way or another. Many families become divided. Sometimes to avoid making such a decision, the family may leave the decision to the doctor who then decides according to his professional judgment and personal conscience.

    Let me illustrate some of the dilemmas with the example of a person dying from terminal cancer with no reasonable hope of recovery. Because the patient's body is weak, his heart may stop beating. Should the doctor try to resuscitate? And if so,

Column: 352

how often? Or if the dying cancer patient is suffering from pneumonia which in fact is the way death naturally takes its course, should the doctor prescribe expensive antibiotics which may clear the immediate infection but leave the underlying condition unchanged? Of if the patient is in severe pain, should morphine be given when that morphine may itself reduce the body's will to live?

    These are difficult decisions to make. They are not only medical decisions, they are also moral decisions. Doctors may not be prepared to make such decisions on behalf of families, especially when they are liable to be sued. As Singaporeans become more educated and aware of the medical alternatives available, civil suits will become more common and doctors may become more inclined to do the safe thing from a legal point of view, than to do the right thing from a professional or a moral standpoint.

    If the patient, while he is compos mentis, has clearly made known his wishes in full knowledge of the alternatives, the decision becomes much easier on both family members and doctors. And this is the purpose of the Advance Medical Directive (AMD) - to allow the patient to make his wishes known in advance clearly and unambiguously. The AMD will remove any doubt as to the patient's own preferences.

    The AMD is based on the principle of patient autonomy. Under common law, every patient has the right to decide whether to accept or reject the treatment that is offered to him by a doctor, and this is also the position of all the major religions. The AMD allows him to make and register that decision in advance so that his wish can guide his treatment when he is unconscious or no longer of sound mind.

    As the AMD touches on life and death, we must take into account the views of all segments of our multi-cultural and multi-religious society. It is for this reason that the National Medical Ethics Committee (NMEC) conducted wide-ranging consultations with all the major religious groups in Singapore before submitting its report.

Column: 353

After consultations with 24 religious and professional organisations, the NMEC has published a report recommending the legislation of AMDs. The Ministry of Health has accepted the report and taken all their recommendations into consideration when drafting the Advance Medical Directive Bill.

    Let me now highlight the main features of the Bill. The Bill allows a person of sound mind who has attained the age of 21 years and who desires not to be subjected to extraordinary life-sustaining treatment when he is suffering from a terminal illness to make an AMD on a prescribed form. The making of an AMD is entirely voluntary. Any person who by deception, fraud or undue influence causes a person to make an AMD will be guilty of an offence under the Act. The penalty for such an offence is a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or both.

    The making of an AMD must be witnessed by two persons of at least 21 years old, one of whom must be a doctor, preferably the patient's family or regular doctor. To prevent coercion and conflict of interests, witnesses must not be persons who stand to benefit from the death of the patient. While this will exclude immediate family members as witnesses, we will encourage every person making an AMD to discuss his decision with his family so that they are aware of his wishes. The doctor who is a witness will be required to explain to the patient on the medical implications of making an AMD, and preferably in the presence of family members. The making of an AMD should not be kept a secret from immediate family members.

    The AMD only applies to the specific clinical condition of "terminal illness" as defined in the Bill. "Terminal illness" is defined as a condition that is incurable, with no reasonable prospect of recovery and where death is imminent, whether or not extraordinary life-sustaining treatment is provided, and where such treatment will only postpone the moment of death. Certification of "terminal illness" is strictly controlled by a process requiring unanimous agreement by three doctors,

Column: 354

two of whom must be specialists. If there is no unanimity, a committee of three specialists drawn from an independent panel of specialists established by the Ministry of Health for this purpose will be consulted. Unless the decision of this committee is unanimous, the patient will not be certified to be terminally ill and the AMD will not take effect. This comprehensive procedure will ensure that an AMD will only take effect after due professional consideration has been given to the clinical condition, the diagnosis and the prognosis. Where there is any doubt, this procedure will ensure that we err on the side of life.

    The Bill provides for a central register of AMDs to be established and maintained by the Ministry. All AMDs must be registered in the register which shall be kept confidential. Access to the register will be strictly controlled. This is to ensure that the existence of an AMD is never allowed to influence medical treatment decisions before the patient is certified to be terminally ill. Under the Bill, it will be an offence for any person to require or prohibit the making of an AMD as a condition for receiving medical services or for being insured. It will also be an offence for a doctor or hospital to ask a patient about the existence of an AMD or about his intention to make an AMD.

    Those who have made AMDs must of course be allowed to change their minds. The Bill therefore provides for easy revocation made orally, in writing or in any other way. The revocation can be made at any time so long as it is witnessed by two persons. In other words, we deliberately make it easier for an AMD to be revoked than for it to be made. This is better than the alternative of making the directive valid for only a fixed period of time and requiring it to be renewed periodically.

    In the NMEC's dialogue with professional medical bodies, the need for a conscientious objector clause was raised. The Bill provides for doctors and those who work for them to register their conscientious objections to the AMD. Doctors who are conscientious objectors

Column: 355

are excluded from participating as witnesses to the making of AMDs and from the certification of terminal illnesses.

    Let me now address three specific concerns that have been raised. The first concern has been that legislation for AMDs is the first step down the "slippery slope of euthanasia". Let me state clearly and categorically that the Ministry of Health, the NMEC and the medical profession in general are all opposed to euthanasia. And this position is fully reflected in the Bill. Clause 17(1) of the Bill states that nothing in the Act "shall authorise an act that causes or accelerates death as distinct from an act that permits the dying process to take its natural course". To remove any doubt whatsoever, clause 17(2) of the Bill declares that "nothing in this Act shall condone, authorise or approve abetment of suicide, mercy killing or euthanasia". Abetment of suicide, mercy killing and euthanasia will thus remain as criminal offences punishable under our Penal Code.

    The provisions of the Bill also ensure that the AMD cannot be used indirectly to allow an act of mercy killing or euthanasia. The definitions of "terminal illness" and "extraordinary life-sustaining treatment" are specific and do not allow any flexibility of interpretation to include mercy killing. The Bill also ensures that even when an AMD has taken effect, palliative care including the provision of food and water must still continue. In fact, we have deliberately discarded the term "Living Will" because of its association with the euthanasia movement.

    There are some who argue that the very act of legislating AMDs makes legal euthanasia more likely in the future. I do not agree. Legislation is the prerogative of Parliament. We cannot predetermine what the Parliament of tomorrow will legislate. In our democratic system, we have the right and the responsibility to elect those who will protect our best interests. Reflecting the majority view of Singaporeans today, the Advance Medical Directive Bill is unambiguous about our opposition to euthanasia. By itself, the

Column: 356

Bill does not make legal euthanasia more or less likely in the future. Indeed, it could well be argued that once AMD legislation is in place, legal euthanasia will become less likely because a major area of ambiguity has been removed.

    The second concern is that we are introducing AMDs to reduce healthcare costs. The two are not directly related. Whether or not we have AMDs, the decision whether or not to make use of extraordinary life-sustaining treatment must still be made either by the patient himself, his family members or by doctors. No individual, no family, no society can escape having to weigh the competing claims of young and old, or the healthy versus the sick, and of the living versus the dying. We do not want healthcare costs to become a crushing burden on our society regardless of how that burden is apportioned among the State, employers, families and individuals. We do this by striking a good balance between market pricing and subsidies, and by controlling the introduction of medical technologies that are not proven to be cost-effective. AMDs are an entirely separate matter. No one can be forced to make an AMD. If an individual chooses to make an AMD, it is his own decision. AMDs may well have the effect of lowering healthcare costs to the individual and his family, and even the State too if the patient is subsidised, but that is not the purpose of introducing it. AMDs will, however, reduce the need and the cost of medical litigation.

    The third concern that has been expressed is that while the principle of the AMD is acceptable, there is no need for legislation at this point in time. In fact, the legal position concerning the withholding or withdrawing of extraordinary life-sustaining treatment is not clear in Singapore today. In the absence of legislation, we make the assumption that the broad principles of common law will apply, including English common law. In an area that is culturally sensitive, this uncertainty is not desirable. Having Parliament legislate will remove any ambiguity as to the scope and legal effect of AMDs. More importantly, legislation ensures that what is acceptable to us is

Column: 357

consistent with our own social consensus and beliefs and not dependent on decisions made in other jurisdictions.

    Even in the UK, the thinking on the need for legislation has changed. The British Medical Association which earlier opposed separate legislation for advance medical directives has since recommended in January 1994 that it favours the concept of limited legislation. More recently, the Law Commission of the United Kingdom in its publication Mental Incapacity released in March 1995 endorsed the principle of "advance statements about health" which are in fact advance medical directives and recommends supporting legislation to remove any ambiguity in the law. In Singapore, the need for legislation has been supported by both the Academy of Law and the Law Society. Legislation for AMDs is not new and already exists in one form or another in Australia, Canada and the USA. We have studied carefully the legislation in these jurisdictions and have used their experiences to guide us in the drafting of our Bill.

    Some have also argued that there is no need for legislation today because the clinical situations for which AMDs apply are not many. That is not an argument against legislation because the need already exists. It is a facility which should be made available to those who wish to take on the moral burden of making their own decisions. We must also prepare for the future. With the speed at which medical technology is advancing, there will be more ways for the dying process to be prolonged by extraordinary life-sustaining means. Our population is also ageing rapidly. The incidence of cancers, strokes and other chronic degenerative diseases will rise. We can therefore expect more Singaporeans wanting to make AMDs in the next 20 to 30 years.

    However, I agree that we should not rush to legislate. Indeed, the NMEC was meticulous in its study and consultations, and took over a year to submit its report. Even so, I propose to refer this Bill to a Select Committee to ensure that all views are taken into account in the final legislation.
